questions.stem: A 68-year-old right-handed woman is brought to the emergency department after sudden onset of right-sided weakness affecting her face and arm more than her leg, along with difficulty producing speech. Her comprehension appears relatively intact. Which artery is most likely occluded, and what is the expected aphasia classification?

options.text: Right middle cerebral artery; Wernicke's aphasia
Left middle cerebral artery; Broca's aphasia
Left anterior cerebral artery; global aphasia
Left posterior cerebral artery; conduction aphasia

questions.explanation: The presentation describes contralateral (right-sided) hemiparesis affecting face and arm more than leg, which is the classic pattern of middle cerebral artery (MCA) stroke. The nonfluent speech with relatively intact comprehension indicates Broca's aphasia, which results from damage to the left inferior frontal gyrus (Broca's area) in the left MCA territory. The MCA is the most commonly affected artery in ischemic stroke.

questions.stem: A patient with a right parietal lobe lesion eats food only from the right side of her plate, draws only the right half of a clock face, and dresses only the right side of her body. When her left arm is shown to her, she denies it is hers. The combination of hemispatial neglect and unawareness of her deficit is best described as:

options.text: Left hemispatial neglect with visual agnosia
Left hemispatial neglect with anosognosia
Right hemispatial neglect with prosopagnosia
Left homonymous hemianopia with confabulation

questions.explanation: Left hemispatial neglect results from right parietal lobe damage and involves failure to attend to stimuli in contralateral (left) space. This is an attentional deficit, not a sensory one. Anosognosia refers to unawareness or denial of one's own neurological deficit, which is commonly associated with right hemisphere (particularly right MCA territory) lesions. The combination of left neglect and anosognosia is a classic right parietal/right MCA stroke presentation.

questions.stem: Which of the following TBI findings is most commonly associated with prolonged coma and persistent vegetative state?

options.text: Epidural hematoma from middle meningeal artery rupture
Focal contusion at the site of impact (coup injury)
Diffuse axonal injury from rotational acceleration-deceleration forces
Subdural hematoma from bridging vein rupture

questions.explanation: Diffuse axonal injury (DAI) results from rotational acceleration-deceleration forces that shear axons throughout the brain. DAI is the most common cause of prolonged coma and persistent vegetative state following TBI because the widespread axonal disruption disconnects brain regions from each other globally, rather than causing focal damage like contusions or hematomas.

questions.stem: A patient produces fluent, well-articulated speech with normal prosody and grammar, but the output contains numerous paraphasias and neologisms that render it largely incomprehensible. The patient does not appear to understand questions or commands and cannot repeat phrases. This presentation is most consistent with:

options.text: Broca's aphasia from left inferior frontal gyrus damage
Conduction aphasia from arcuate fasciculus damage
Wernicke's aphasia from left posterior superior temporal gyrus damage
Anomic aphasia from variable cortical damage

questions.explanation: Wernicke's aphasia is characterized by fluent speech (normal rate, prosody, and grammar) that is largely meaningless ('word salad'), severely impaired comprehension, and impaired repetition. The lesion involves the left posterior superior temporal gyrus (Wernicke's area). Conduction aphasia also has fluent output but is distinguished by intact comprehension with severely impaired repetition. Anomic aphasia features only word-finding difficulty with intact fluency, comprehension, and repetition.

questions.stem: A 72-year-old man experiences a 15-minute episode of right arm weakness and slurred speech that resolves completely. His neurological examination one hour later is entirely normal. This event is best classified as a:

options.text: Completed ischemic stroke with rapid recovery
Transient ischemic attack (TIA)
Hemorrhagic stroke with spontaneous resolution
Focal seizure with postictal paralysis (Todd's paralysis)

questions.explanation: A transient ischemic attack (TIA) produces temporary stroke-like symptoms that resolve completely within 24 hours, typically within minutes. The complete resolution of focal neurological deficits is the defining feature. TIAs are a major warning sign and significantly increase the risk of subsequent stroke, requiring urgent evaluation. While Todd's paralysis is in the differential, the clinical description of sudden onset focal weakness and speech difficulty with complete resolution is most characteristic of TIA.

questions.stem: Select ALL features that are characteristic of a right middle cerebral artery (MCA) stroke in a right-handed individual:

options.text: Left-sided hemiparesis affecting face and arm more than leg
Broca's aphasia with telegraphic speech output
Left hemispatial neglect and anosognosia
Constructional apraxia on visuospatial tasks
Right homonymous hemianopia

questions.explanation: Right MCA stroke produces contralateral (left-sided) hemiparesis with face and arm more affected than leg, left hemispatial neglect, anosognosia (unawareness of deficit), and constructional apraxia. Broca's aphasia would result from a LEFT MCA stroke, not right, since language is left-lateralized in the vast majority of right-handed individuals. Right homonymous hemianopia would result from a left-sided lesion affecting the optic radiations, not a right MCA stroke.

questions.stem: Select ALL of the following that correctly describe components of the Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS):

options.text: Eye opening is scored from 1 to 4
Verbal response is scored from 1 to 5
Motor response is scored from 1 to 6
A GCS score of 13-15 classifies a TBI as moderate
The minimum possible GCS score is 3, indicating deep coma

questions.explanation: The GCS assesses three domains: eye opening (1-4), verbal response (1-5), and motor response (1-6), yielding total scores from 3 (deep coma) to 15 (fully alert). A GCS of 13-15 classifies TBI as mild (not moderate). Moderate TBI corresponds to GCS scores of 9-12, and severe TBI to scores of 3-8.

questions.stem: Select ALL characteristics that distinguish ischemic stroke from hemorrhagic stroke:

options.text: Ischemic stroke accounts for approximately 87% of all strokes
Hemorrhagic stroke has a higher mortality rate than ischemic stroke
Ischemic stroke can be treated with tPA if administered within 4.5 hours
Hemorrhagic stroke is caused by blockage from a thrombus or embolus
Hemorrhagic stroke is often associated with hypertension or aneurysm

questions.explanation: Ischemic stroke (~87% of strokes) results from arterial blockage (thrombus or embolus) and can be treated with tPA within 4.5 hours. Hemorrhagic stroke (~13%) results from vessel rupture (not blockage), has higher mortality, and is often associated with hypertension or aneurysm. Option D incorrectly describes the mechanism of hemorrhagic stroke -- blockage by thrombus or embolus is the mechanism of ischemic stroke.

questions.stem: Select ALL features commonly associated with post-concussion syndrome following mild TBI:

options.text: Persistent headache and dizziness
Difficulty concentrating and sleep disturbance
Fatigue and irritability
Accumulation of tau protein visible on standard neuroimaging
Progressive dementia requiring definitive post-mortem diagnosis

questions.explanation: Post-concussion syndrome involves persistent symptoms after mild TBI including headache, dizziness, fatigue, irritability, difficulty concentrating, and sleep disturbance, typically resolving within weeks to months. Options D and E describe features of chronic traumatic encephalopathy (CTE), not post-concussion syndrome. CTE is a progressive neurodegenerative disease associated with repeated head impacts, characterized by tau accumulation, and currently requires post-mortem examination for definitive diagnosis.

questions.stem: Select ALL statements that are true regarding absence seizures (petit mal):

options.text: They involve brief lapses in consciousness lasting 5-30 seconds
They are most common in children and are often mistaken for daydreaming
They show a characteristic 3 Hz spike-and-wave pattern on EEG
They typically include a tonic phase followed by a clonic phase
They may include subtle automatisms such as lip smacking or eye blinking

questions.explanation: Absence seizures (petit mal) are characterized by brief lapses in consciousness (5-30 seconds), staring, subtle automatisms, a characteristic 3 Hz spike-and-wave pattern on EEG, and are common in children. They are often mistaken for daydreaming. Tonic-clonic phases are features of generalized tonic-clonic (grand mal) seizures, not absence seizures.

questions.stem: Match each aphasia type with its defining characteristic pattern:

columns.text: Fluent speech, intact comprehension, severely impaired repetition
Nonfluent telegraphic speech, relatively intact comprehension, impaired repetition
Fluent speech, intact comprehension, intact repetition, word-finding difficulty only
Fluent word salad, severely impaired comprehension, impaired repetition

questions.explanation: Broca's aphasia features nonfluent, telegraphic speech with relatively intact comprehension and impaired repetition (left inferior frontal gyrus). Wernicke's aphasia features fluent but meaningless 'word salad' with severely impaired comprehension and impaired repetition (left posterior superior temporal gyrus). Conduction aphasia features fluent speech with intact comprehension but severely impaired repetition (arcuate fasciculus). Anomic aphasia features fluent speech with intact comprehension and repetition, with only word-finding difficulty (variable lesion site).

questions.stem: Match each seizure type with its most characteristic feature:

columns.text: Continuous seizure activity >5 minutes; medical emergency requiring IV benzodiazepines
Brief consciousness lapses (5-30 sec) with 3 Hz spike-and-wave EEG; common in children
Loss of consciousness, stiffening phase, rhythmic jerking, postictal confusion
Most commonly temporal lobe origin; may include deja vu, fear, and lip smacking automatisms

questions.explanation: Generalized tonic-clonic seizures involve loss of consciousness, a tonic phase (stiffening), a clonic phase (rhythmic jerking), and postictal confusion. Absence seizures feature brief consciousness lapses with characteristic 3 Hz spike-and-wave on EEG. Focal seizures with impaired awareness most commonly originate in the temporal lobe and may include experiential phenomena (deja vu, fear) and automatisms (lip smacking). Status epilepticus is continuous seizure activity lasting >5 minutes, constituting a medical emergency treated with IV benzodiazepines.

questions.stem: For each type of brain injury, select ALL clinical features that are typically associated with it. Some features may apply to more than one injury type.
questions.explanation: Coup-contrecoup injuries particularly affect the frontal and temporal lobes due to contact with rough bony surfaces of the cranial fossae. Left MCA stroke produces aphasia (Broca's or Wernicke's depending on the branch affected) since language is typically left-lateralized. Right MCA stroke produces left hemispatial neglect due to disruption of right-hemisphere spatial attention networks. Diffuse axonal injury is the most common cause of prolonged coma and persistent vegetative state due to widespread axonal shearing.

questions.stem: For each aphasia type, select ALL correct descriptors. Multiple descriptors may apply to each aphasia type.
questions.explanation: Global aphasia involves impaired repetition and severely impaired comprehension (nonfluent output as well, affecting all language modalities from a large left MCA territory lesion). Broca's aphasia features impaired repetition with relatively intact (not severely impaired) comprehension and nonfluent output. Wernicke's aphasia features impaired repetition, fluent output, and severely impaired comprehension. Conduction aphasia features impaired repetition (severely so), fluent output, and intact comprehension (arcuate fasciculus lesion).

questions.stem: The Glasgow Coma Scale assesses three components: eye opening scored from 1 to {{blank1}}, verbal response scored from 1 to {{blank2}}, and motor response scored from 1 to {{blank3}}. A total GCS score of 3-8 indicates {{blank4}} TBI.

options.text: mild
moderate
severe
critical

questions.explanation: The GCS assesses eye opening (1-4), verbal response (1-5), and motor response (1-6), producing scores from 3 to 15. Motor response has the largest range (1-6) because it provides the most reliable prognostic information. GCS scores classify TBI as: mild (13-15), moderate (9-12), and severe (3-8).

questions.stem: Ischemic stroke accounts for approximately {{blank1}} of all strokes and is caused by {{blank2}} of a cerebral artery. The time-sensitive treatment for ischemic stroke is {{blank3}}, which must be administered within {{blank4}} of symptom onset.

options.text: rupture
blockage
inflammation
vasospasm
IV heparin
tPA (tissue plasminogen activator)
IV nimodipine
aspirin bolus
1 hour
3 hours
4.5 hours
8 hours

questions.explanation: Ischemic stroke accounts for approximately 87% of all strokes and results from blockage of a cerebral artery by a thrombus (clot forming in situ) or embolus (clot traveling from elsewhere). The treatment is tPA (tissue plasminogen activator), a thrombolytic that must be administered within 4.5 hours of symptom onset. tPA is contraindicated in hemorrhagic stroke, which is why CT imaging to rule out hemorrhage is critical before treatment.

questions.stem: A 55-year-old retired professional football player presents with progressive mood disturbance, impulsivity, difficulty with executive functions, and memory decline over the past several years. His wife reports personality changes including increased irritability and episodes of poor judgment. He has a history of multiple concussions during his career.

options.text: History of repeated head impacts from contact sports
Accumulation of hyperphosphorylated tau protein
Single severe TBI with prolonged loss of consciousness
Accumulation of beta-amyloid plaques and prion proteins
Chronic traumatic encephalopathy (CTE)
Post-concussion syndrome
Alzheimer's disease
Definitive diagnosis currently requires post-mortem examination
Progressive neurodegenerative course with mood and cognitive changes
Symptoms typically resolve within weeks to months
Can be definitively diagnosed with PET amyloid imaging during life

questions.explanation: CTE is a progressive neurodegenerative disease associated with repeated head impacts (common in contact sports and military personnel). It is characterized by accumulation of hyperphosphorylated tau protein (not amyloid plaques, which characterize Alzheimer's). CTE produces mood disturbance, impulsivity, cognitive decline, and eventually dementia. Unlike post-concussion syndrome (which resolves), CTE is progressive. Definitive diagnosis currently requires post-mortem neuropathological examination, though research on in vivo biomarkers is ongoing.

questions.stem: A 70-year-old right-handed woman suddenly develops difficulty speaking. Her speech is effortful, halting, and telegraphic (e.g., 'walk...dog...morning'). She follows commands appropriately and appears to understand questions but becomes visibly frustrated when she cannot express herself verbally. She has right-sided facial droop and right arm weakness.

options.text: Lesion in the left inferior frontal gyrus (Brodmann areas 44/45)
Left middle cerebral artery ischemic stroke
Lesion in the left posterior superior temporal gyrus
Damage to the right arcuate fasciculus
Broca's aphasia (expressive aphasia)
Wernicke's aphasia (receptive aphasia)
Global aphasia
Nonfluent, telegraphic speech output with impaired repetition
Relatively intact auditory comprehension
Fluent but meaningless speech output (word salad)
Severely impaired comprehension of spoken language

questions.explanation: Broca's aphasia results from damage to the left inferior frontal gyrus (Broca's area, Brodmann areas 44/45), typically from a left MCA stroke affecting the superior division. Key features include nonfluent, telegraphic speech, impaired repetition, and relatively intact comprehension. The patient's frustration reflects awareness of the deficit (unlike Wernicke's aphasia patients, who often lack insight). The accompanying right facial droop and arm weakness confirm left MCA territory involvement.

questions.stem: Highlight ALL statements that are clinically accurate regarding cerebrovascular disease and brain injury.
questions.passage: A neuropsychologist is reviewing key facts about stroke and TBI for a clinical presentation. [Ischemic stroke, caused by arterial blockage, accounts for approximately 87% of all strokes and can be treated with tPA within 4.5 hours of onset]. [Hemorrhagic stroke results from arterial blockage and accounts for the majority of stroke cases]. [In coup-contrecoup TBI, the frontal and temporal lobes are particularly vulnerable because they contact the rough bony surfaces of the anterior and middle cranial fossae]. [A transient ischemic attack (TIA) produces permanent neurological deficits that worsen progressively over days]. [Hemispatial neglect from right parietal damage is an attentional deficit, not a sensory deficit, meaning the visual system can detect stimuli but the attentional system fails to process them]. [Conduction aphasia is characterized by nonfluent speech, severely impaired comprehension, and intact repetition].

highlightableSegments.text: Ischemic stroke, caused by arterial blockage, accounts for approximately 87% of all strokes and can be treated with tPA within 4.5 hours of onset
Hemorrhagic stroke results from arterial blockage and accounts for the majority of stroke cases
In coup-contrecoup TBI, the frontal and temporal lobes are particularly vulnerable because they contact the rough bony surfaces of the anterior and middle cranial fossae
A transient ischemic attack (TIA) produces permanent neurological deficits that worsen progressively over days
Hemispatial neglect from right parietal damage is an attentional deficit, not a sensory deficit, meaning the visual system can detect stimuli but the attentional system fails to process them
Conduction aphasia is characterized by nonfluent speech, severely impaired comprehension, and intact repetition

questions.explanation: Statements 1, 3, and 5 are correct. Statement 2 is wrong: hemorrhagic stroke results from vessel rupture (not blockage) and accounts for only ~13% of strokes. Statement 4 is wrong: TIAs produce temporary symptoms that resolve completely within 24 hours. Statement 6 is wrong: conduction aphasia features fluent speech (not nonfluent), intact comprehension (not impaired), and severely impaired repetition (not intact).

questions.stem: Highlight ALL clinically accurate statements about seizure disorders.
questions.passage: A neurology resident is preparing a teaching presentation on epilepsy. [Absence seizures (petit mal) feature brief consciousness lapses of 5-30 seconds and show a characteristic 3 Hz spike-and-wave pattern on EEG]. [Generalized tonic-clonic seizures begin with a clonic phase of rhythmic jerking followed by a tonic stiffening phase]. [Status epilepticus is a medical emergency defined as continuous seizure activity lasting more than 5 minutes, treated with IV benzodiazepines]. [Focal seizures with impaired awareness most commonly originate in the temporal lobe and may include experiential phenomena such as deja vu and fear]. [Absence seizures are most common in elderly adults and are characterized by violent convulsive movements]. [Focal seizures with preserved awareness involve seizure activity confined to one brain region with consciousness maintained].

highlightableSegments.text: Absence seizures (petit mal) feature brief consciousness lapses of 5-30 seconds and show a characteristic 3 Hz spike-and-wave pattern on EEG
Generalized tonic-clonic seizures begin with a clonic phase of rhythmic jerking followed by a tonic stiffening phase
Status epilepticus is a medical emergency defined as continuous seizure activity lasting more than 5 minutes, treated with IV benzodiazepines
Focal seizures with impaired awareness most commonly originate in the temporal lobe and may include experiential phenomena such as deja vu and fear
Absence seizures are most common in elderly adults and are characterized by violent convulsive movements
Focal seizures with preserved awareness involve seizure activity confined to one brain region with consciousness maintained

questions.explanation: Statements 1, 3, 4, and 6 are correct. Statement 2 is wrong because generalized tonic-clonic seizures begin with the tonic phase (stiffening) FOLLOWED by the clonic phase (rhythmic jerking), not the reverse. Statement 5 is wrong because absence seizures are most common in children (not elderly adults) and involve brief consciousness lapses with subtle automatisms, not violent convulsive movements.

questions.stem: Arrange the following steps in the correct sequence for clinical management of a patient presenting with sudden-onset neurological deficits suggesting acute stroke:

items.text: Rapid neurological assessment and establish time of symptom onset
Emergent CT scan to rule out hemorrhagic stroke
If ischemic stroke confirmed and within treatment window, administer tPA
Monitor in intensive care for hemorrhagic transformation and neurological changes
Comprehensive neuropsychological assessment of cognitive deficits once medically stable
Initiate rehabilitation program (PT, OT, speech therapy) based on identified deficits

questions.explanation: Acute stroke management follows a time-critical sequence: (1) Rapid assessment including establishing symptom onset time (critical for determining tPA eligibility); (2) Emergent CT to distinguish ischemic from hemorrhagic stroke (tPA is contraindicated in hemorrhage); (3) tPA administration if ischemic and within 4.5-hour window; (4) ICU monitoring for complications; (5) Neuropsychological assessment once medically stable to characterize cognitive deficits; (6) Targeted rehabilitation based on the assessment findings.

questions.stem: Arrange the following phases of a generalized tonic-clonic (grand mal) seizure in the correct temporal sequence:

items.text: Aura (warning sensation, if present) -- may include sensory experiences or emotional changes
Loss of consciousness and fall to the ground
Tonic phase: sustained muscle stiffening/contraction throughout the body
Clonic phase: rhythmic jerking movements of the extremities
Cessation of motor activity with muscular relaxation
Postictal phase: confusion, fatigue, headache, and gradual return to baseline (minutes to hours)

questions.explanation: A generalized tonic-clonic seizure follows a characteristic sequence: (1) An aura may precede the seizure, especially if it begins focally before generalizing; (2) Abrupt loss of consciousness; (3) The tonic phase involves sustained muscle contraction/stiffening; (4) The clonic phase follows with rhythmic jerking; (5) Motor activity ceases and muscles relax; (6) The postictal phase involves confusion, fatigue, and gradual recovery, lasting minutes to hours. The tonic phase always precedes the clonic phase.

questions.stem: A research team is tracking cognitive and functional outcomes in a sample of patients following moderate TBI. They measure executive function (via Wisconsin Card Sorting Test), memory (via list-learning tasks), and processing speed at regular intervals over the first two years post-injury.
questions.question: Which interpretation best describes the recovery trajectory shown in this data?

options.text: All cognitive domains show linear, continuous improvement at the same rate through 24 months
The most rapid recovery occurs in the first 6 months, with a plateau effect as gains diminish between 12 and 24 months
Processing speed fully recovers to normal (T=50) while executive function and memory remain severely impaired
Memory shows the fastest recovery, surpassing both executive function and processing speed by 24 months

questions.explanation: The data show that all three cognitive domains improve most rapidly in the first 6 months post-TBI, with the rate of improvement slowing significantly between 12 and 24 months (plateau effect). This is consistent with the well-established TBI recovery curve: neuroplastic recovery is most active in the early months, with diminishing returns over time. None of the domains fully return to the normative mean (T=50), and all three follow a similar trajectory, which is typical of moderate TBI recovery.

questions.stem: A longitudinal study compares functional independence scores (FIM) between patients with single ischemic stroke versus patients with multiple recurrent strokes over a 5-year period. Both groups receive standard rehabilitation.
questions.question: Which conclusion is best supported by these data regarding functional outcomes after stroke?

options.text: Both groups show continuous improvement, with the recurrent stroke group improving more slowly
The single stroke group shows recovery and functional plateau, while the recurrent stroke group shows initial improvement followed by stepwise decline with each subsequent vascular event
Rehabilitation is effective only for the single stroke group and provides no benefit for recurrent stroke patients
The single stroke group declines after Year 3 at the same rate as the recurrent stroke group

questions.explanation: The single stroke group shows the expected recovery pattern: significant improvement in the first year, continued modest gains through Year 2-3, and functional plateau. The recurrent stroke group initially improves but then shows a stepwise decline pattern consistent with additional vascular events (each new stroke produces further functional loss). This stepwise deterioration is the hallmark of vascular neurocognitive disorder and contrasts with the gradual, continuous decline seen in Alzheimer's disease.

questions.stem: Categorize each clinical feature as characteristic of the appropriate aphasia type:

items.text: Nonfluent, effortful, telegraphic speech
Fluent but meaningless word salad output
Severely impaired repetition with intact comprehension
Relatively intact comprehension despite impaired output
Severely impaired auditory comprehension
Lesion of the arcuate fasciculus

questions.explanation: Broca's aphasia features nonfluent, telegraphic speech with relatively intact comprehension (left inferior frontal gyrus lesion). Wernicke's aphasia features fluent word salad with severely impaired comprehension (left posterior superior temporal gyrus lesion). Conduction aphasia features the unique profile of fluent speech with intact comprehension but severely impaired repetition, resulting from damage to the arcuate fasciculus that connects Wernicke's area to Broca's area.

questions.stem: Categorize each clinical scenario as most consistent with the appropriate stroke/injury type:

items.text: Treated with tPA within 4.5 hours of symptom onset
Vessel rupture often associated with hypertension or aneurysm
Temporary neurological deficits resolving completely within 24 hours
Accounts for approximately 87% of all stroke cases
Higher mortality rate; intracerebral or subarachnoid bleeding
Major warning sign significantly increasing future stroke risk

questions.explanation: Ischemic stroke (~87% of strokes) is caused by arterial blockage and treated with tPA within 4.5 hours. Hemorrhagic stroke (~13%) results from vessel rupture associated with hypertension or aneurysm and has higher mortality, with bleeding either intracerebral or subarachnoid. TIA produces temporary neurological symptoms that resolve completely within 24 hours and serves as a major warning sign for future stroke, requiring urgent evaluation and secondary prevention.
